awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unlocking the evolutionary history of Schiedea (carnation family, Caryophyllaceae): rapid radiation of an endemic plant genus in the Hawaiian Islands
awd_abstract_narration:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Plants exhibit a diverse array of breeding strategies, but the genetic changes and environmental conditions that lead to this diversity are poorly known. Pinpointing these genetic mutations and understanding the environmental conditions that favor changes in breeding system are of great interest to both evolutionary biologists and plant breeders. The plant genus Schiedea (carnation family, Caryophyllaceae) is only found on the Hawaiian Islands and is a model to better understand the evolution of breeding strategies in plants. Among the 32 species of Schiedea, some only breed with other individuals of the same species, others only self-fertilize, and others still are transitional between the two. Additionally, different outbreeding species of Schiedea use different pollinators, including a recently discovered moth found only in Hawaii. This project will apply cutting-edge DNA sequencing and analysis methods to reconstruct the genealogy of Scheidea and investigate the evolution of plant breeding strategies within the group. Data from this project will provide new insights into the evolution of plant breeding strategies that could be applied to crop species in the carnation family, including amaranth, rhubarb, quinoa and spinach. The project incorporates extensive opportunities for education and training at multiple levels, including high school teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher. The project will produce educational videos about Hawaiian plants for posting on the internet to inform the public. Researchers will also offer public seminars about Schiedea highlighting their research findings about the group.



The primary aim of this project is to reconstruct the pattern of breeding system evolution in Schiedea (Caryophyllaceae) through an integrated program of field, laboratory, and genomic studies. Nuclear genome sequencing, targeted sequence capture, and Genotyping By Sequencing (GBS) methods will be used to reconstruct a highly resolved phylogenetic tree of Schiedea, identify sources of phylogenetic conflict, and investigate patterns of introgression among taxa. The phylogenetic hypotheses developed will be used to interpret the evolution of breeding systems including transitions from hermaphroditism to dioecy, shifts from biotic to abiotic pollination, and traits associated with pollination biology (including scent and nectar production). Field studies and densely distributed Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNP) markers generated by GBS will be used to test hypotheses concerning the influence of reproductive systems on gene flow, hybridization, and population genetic structure. Data obtained during this project will be applied directly to land management in Hawaii, including the establishment of wild populations of different Schiedea species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.  Plants on volcanic islands provide outstanding opportunities for understanding evolutionary processes. The Hawaiian Islands are among the most remote islands on the planet and host extraordinary plants that occur nowhere else in the world. Many native Hawaiian plants are highly endangered due to human activities.

Schiedea, one of the most diverse groups consists of 36 species in the carnation family that occur nowhere else in the world. Schiedea serves as a natural laboratory of reproductive evolution: nearly every major type of breeding system occurs within the genus. Some species of Schiedea have individuals with separate sexes while others have flowers with both sexes. Some species with both sexes regularly self-pollinate while others are highly cross-pollinating between plants with pollination by wind, moths, or possibly birds.

The central research goal of this collaborative project was to resolve the evolution of breeding systems in Schiedea using a variety of greenhouse-, field- and laboratory-based techniques. The project involved six institutions: National Tropical Botanical Garden (NTBG), University of California Irvine (UCI), Chicago Botanic Garden, Clemson University, Smithsonian Institution, and Oberlin College. We employed a suite of modern DNA sequencing tools to generate trees of evolutionary relationships for all species in the genus using nearly 900 genes. We also undertook field and greenhouse studies to explore breeding system evolution, ranging from cutting-edge chemical analyses of floral scent to evening field observations of Schiedea flowers in the wild to better understand whether organisms such as moths might act as pollinators. We also did field surveys to collect and estimate the status of populations of all species with collaborators from NTBG, the State of Hawaii conservation staff and also from Pacific Islands Fish&Wildlife Office. Seeds and herbarium specimens were made and many were among the collections provided for the molecular analyses.

Our DNA-based studies have finally resolved the evolutionary relationships of all species in the genus, which promises to greatly enhance our understanding of fine-scale evolutionary processes. For example, our DNA-based studies reveal a complicated history of evolutionary shifts among breeding systems, and clearly document widespread hybridization among the wind-pollinated species of Schiedea. Importantly, our greenhouse studies of reproductive barriers among species, when viewed in light of our DNA-based evolutionary tree, demonstrate that these barriers are weak among close relatives but are stronger among distant relatives. The strength of these patterns is bolstered by the comprehensive sampling of our studies. This greater understanding of the biology of these species helps us better understand how to protect the native species and communities of the Hawaiian Islands.

During our award period, two new Schiedea species were discovered in the Hawaiian Islands by project partners: S. haakoaensis from Hawaii Island and the enigmatic S. waiahuluensis from Kauai. The latter species is the first species ever discovered and collected using drone technologies (see Innovative Drone Technology Discovers New Plant Species in Hawaii  SciTech Daily (17 Nov2024) and Discover Wildlife (28 Nov2024)  https://scitechdaily.com/innovative-drone-technology-discovers-new-plant-species-in-hawaii/ 

https://www.discoverwildlife.com/environment/schiedea-waiahuluensis-kauai-hawaii

Broader Impacts. 

Hawaii conservation workshop. From October 2021 through March 2022, the Schiedea team sponsored a very successful virtual Hawaii Conservation Workshop. The workshop consisted of 10 meetings, each 2-3 hours long, including prepared presentations and discussion about plant conservation, featuring 32 speakers over the course the sessions. Nineteen of those recorded presentations are publicly available for viewing on NMNH’s Natural History for Scientists’ YouTube channel <https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQmxS2U3B6KYo441UojIVJmNBpAu974v1>.

Nearly 200 attendees from various conservation agencies and institutions in Hawaii attended at least one meeting, and each meeting was attended by at least 50 people. Feedback was highly positive from attendees and organizers. In addition, a draft document was generated during the workshop on best practices in developing and integrating conservation genomics into Hawaiian projects.

Outreach to the public.  The award directly supported the creation of two professionally produced educational videos related to project goals filmed on location on Kauai., as part of the Plants Are Cool, Too! YouTube channel. These 15-minute videos are publicly available. One video focuses on the conservation program for endangered Hawaiian plants at NTBG https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GOnuk1naI50&t=3s  and the other explores Schiedea plant conservation  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1zNfODhM4o&t=49s .

Conservation.  The project has supported Schiedea conservation efforts. For example, approximately 200 greenhouse-grown plants of a highly endangered Schiedea were transferred to NTBG and planted on Kauai, where they are being monitored. Likewise, seeds of other endangered species of Schiedea grown by PIs Weller and Sakai have been donated to the NTBG and State of Hawaii seed banks. The field program allowed discovery of new populations of several species by NTBG botanist Ken Wood, and state botanists Adam Williams and Scott Heintzman along with seed collections for seed storage work at NTBG and cultivation in conservation collections. Discoveries of new species with the use of drones opens up new avenues to better understand the distribution and habitats of species in the unique and endangered Hawaiian flora
